author: natnael
title: CA Academy Certification
description: How do we ensure our CAs have enough understanding about our mission at catalyst before assessing proposals?

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is closely aligned with the challenge because it is aimed at improving the onboarding process for community advisors. A web application that serves to educate and onboard people interested in becoming community advisors is a needed tool as catalyst continues to scale. The current process to become a community advisor is radically inclusive and while this comes with many benefits, it also leads to less than optimal proposal assessments. Proposal assessments done by CAs which are not onboarded properly can to misleading messages sent to voters. Overall, a web application built to educate and certify that Community Advisors have a base understand of the catalyst mission and processes would be a valuable improvement to the CA process.
f6_assessments.q1: The plan presented in this proposal is sound and feasible. The proposer communicates experience in software development and educational content creation. The challenge will be to collaborate with as many Catalyst stake holders as possible to create a web application that properly certifies and onboards individuals that want to assess proposals. Overall, this proposal is highly likely to be implemented if funded due to the feasible objectives outlined in the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: With this project looking to involve the community in the development of the web application to certify CAs, it will be easy to track the progress of development. Once developed, the proposal outlines concrete metrics to audit the impact of the onboarding web applications. Overall, should this project be funded, progress should be easy to audit due to many community members being involved in the development and clear metrics to measure surrounding the impact of the web application to improve the onboarding process.

f6_assessments.q0:
The idea of CA academy is good since it will guarantee that any CA assessing proposals is ready to do it because, besides doing previous reading Community Advisor Assessment Guide (https://docs.google.com/document/d/1g-iZhDlKhUBZkui1uv8NVNfJC4oVD3JtR-P6Fue7XPU/edit#heading=h.nvn8rjkdb8jh),  they passed through an examination that certified them as ready and proper CAs.
Once the tool will serve all information the CAs need to evaluate the proposals, it will be really good for the growing knowledge of the community and contribute more and more to the quality and filter of submitted proposals. 
As a critic, I believe that the author could present a mitigation action for the mapped risk. I could suggest already mapping experience community members that are interested on contribute to the project and start scheduling their agendas with meetings where brainstorming will support the development of which information have to be loaded on the boot.
f6_assessments.q1:
For the time feasibility, the plan is well divided into 2 different stages and expected deliverables, but I believe that the stages should be better described in terms of how long time each deliverable will be executed. Also, I would provide milestones for each activity turning it more palpable.  
For the money feasibility, despite a good description, I believe that it should be taken into consideration the number of hours and price per hour each professional will take to guarantee the execution of their activities. Without that information, it seems that the budget wasn’t carefully built by doing proper research with the correct roles and candidates.
 For me, it is important to publish the team that is going to be allocated to run the proposals. In this case, the author mentions what are the roles but do not present them to the public.
f6_assessments.q2: The author understands the importance of KPIs and measurements and indicates good metrics to evaluate how well his project is performing although no KPIs are presented. I suggest the author use the knowledge with the theme to elaborate KPIs based on the performance and results expected and always look into parametrized numbers. Then it is really important to define targets that the team will have to achieve (always remembering that targets must be challenging but feasible to create engagement to the team).

f6_assessments.q0: As a community advisor myself, there has been great controversy, especially on the telegram channel, when it comes to whether the community advisors really are aware of their task and goal. Building an academy for CAs to get a certification that ensures they have the basic tools and knowledge when onboarding on the assessment stage seems like a great idea to me. I think that more quality assessments on the Catalyst proposals will have more than a positive impact on the Cardano ecosystem, as it is a community-driven one with the voters deciding on what is next up to happen. The proposal is in accordance with the challenge. I am also quite positive that this proposal can address future challenges, as the community advisors' area is still amenable to improvements.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer gives account of the members that will be necessary to deliver this proposal as experienced community members, experienced digital content creators and also a number of developers that will be responsible for the web development phase. It is mentioned that the proposer is an experienced community member as well as a software engineer but there are no reference links provided. That also applies to the open calls and applications that will be a part of the roadmap. Where will that take place? Is it going to be to apply to the whole community or a part of it? The type of members required to implement this proposal is mentioned but the number of them is not. The timetable seems a bit unspecific as it is said that it is about 3 months per phase but nothing else is mentioned as to what is going to take place each week or at least each month. The budget is broken down into identifiable items and it seems quite reasonable from my point of view. The resources necessary to implement this idea are referred in the budget section indeed. Something else that the proposer should take into consideration is that there are some risks, as it happens in most proposals being at that an early stage, and they should indicate some awareness of them for the voters to take into consideration.
f6_assessments.q2: I do believe that the time horizon should be a bit more specific as to how the plan is going to roll down. The 3-month piece of information is not enough for a community member to get be able to follow up with the idea. There is also no obvious way to track the progress of the proposal, something that comes down to the non-existent provided links. Maybe a github or twitter account would be useful, if not a whole new site, which i understand will be an addition cost and will need additional resources. There are some KPIs such as the number of community advisors that are going to get enrolled, the number of VCAs that are going to  collaborate for content creation and the number of Certified community advisors that will occur but the exact numbers are not given. How many certified CAs will be enough for the project to be considered a success? How many community advisors will need to get enrolled to begin the certification process? The KPIs need to be more specific for the proposal to be considered more complete.

f6_assessments.q0: By addressing the challenge settings this proposal provides a great service as well as a creating a competitive educational environment for current and future CAs. Although not mentioned, the opportunity for scaling is present; extend certification to vCAs as well. Structured education programs are paramount to onboarding and retaining CAs in Catalyst. As the processes and guidelines change so too will the education. Although a web-interface is preferable I encourage the proposer to constrain the data requirements, weight of interface and insure a mobile-friendly UX/UI  inc consideration of those CAs who may be in less-developed countries. Making the platform lightweight will provide additional impact metrics. Multimedia provides a better learning experience for all involved and has been taken into consideration here. One predetermined area of risk is the quantity of input from community members pertaining to content creation. One risk that persist amongst all projects: Adoption. And adoption would likely be a risk here as well. Ultimately, I look forward to seeing this implemented in the future.
f6_assessments.q1: The depth of team experience is not well defined but addressed and the overall detail and composition of the proposal does provide some insight into the proposer’s experience. Additional individuals are not listed but their respective roles are; the proposer appears to dance around their prospects while also stating that some functional areas require community members and vCAs. Perhaps this is a team of one, the proposer, who will be adding team members upon funding approval. The well-outlined plan and reasonable budget are a great display of intent. Of minimal concern, but still a requirement, is the absence of a timeline outside of a 3-month block. It would be beneficial for the proposer to provide a clearer timeline in future proposals or upon resubmission, along with a clearer status of relevant team members.
f6_assessments.q2: While this project is auditable and KPIs are provided, there are no clear methods of interim auditing provided. No possible repos or other platform visitations allow for insight.  It is only after completion that auditing will become possible via a web-interface or website. It is recommended that the proposer provide, for instance, a repo showing data collection, usage, organization of materials, etc. so the community may periodically review the processes and supporting documentation. Overall the proposal is well written, clear and concise with the exception of team members, community members notwithstanding, and a clear timeline aside from the 3 months as stated. The proposer should address these issues, possibly in comments, or in a re-submittal.

f6_assessments.q0: Implement an e-learning platofrm will facilitate the training of new Community Advisors and will be a response to one the the goals of the this challenge to which this proposal respond by suggesting the idea of creating this CA Academy certification.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposers team is composed by members who have been involved with the Catalyst on different role. By having that insight help them be able propose ideas that would be successful lwo the community for their training to becomem CAs.

f6_assessments.q2: The indicators are well presented and the community may audit the progress of the project implementation as it's an online platform

f6_assessments.q0:
The aim of this proposal is to build a CA Academy, a web-based e-learning platform dedicated to Catalyst CAs.
However, there are already a lot of websites and workshops dedicated to CAs, plus Catalyst School and from personal experience I do not feel the need to attend any of those - though I have been watching them, as the official assessment guidelines from IOHK, the ones that are being presented every fund and are the main reference point for all the other guides, are more than sufficient.
The main point with CAs, in my understanding (having been a CA starting with Fund5), is that they should be able to understand written text quite easily - especially considering that the Catalyst proposals are also in written text - and should start experimenting with being a CA, and get the hang of it while being active. 
Too much feeded information from the beginning risks having all CAs doing the reviews in the same way, loosing bit by bit the decentralisation.
As such, from the information that has been provided, I do not see this proposal as having a (positive) impact on the Catalyst and Cardano ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1:
The plan presented is quite detailed, offering all the steps necessary for the development of the project. The process envisioned is divided into 2 main phases, each requiring approximately 3 months for completion, with some of the steps even overlapping. 
The budget is divided per main categories, though there also should have been the hours needed described, or a price per hour given, that would have justified the amounts requested.
The proposer should have given at least a detailed description about himself, coupled with a social profile link, and a detailed description of the developer skills needed to implement the technical side.
As for the CAs needed to start building the learning documentation, I would recommend describing how he plans on incentivising them to offer their time for this, more beyond the short mention in the budget “Experienced community members incentive for collaborating $1500”.
Considering the lacking information in the budget and team members, I find it hard to assess the team’s capabilities in implementing the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2:
The progress development should have had a description of how the proposer will measure the advancement of the project, based on the timeline he has provided, there should also be a way for the community to check if those steps have been implemented, without the direct input from the proposing team.
As for the succes description, there should have also been some clear milestones attached to the points described, that would have also helped the community in assessing the positive outcome of the project. For example, the first point mentioned “Number of community advisors enrolled” should also include a clear number, XX number of CAs enrolled in the first XX months, as that way the community would be able to clearly assess the success of the proposal.
Given the lack of information in this category, I find it hard to correctly assess the progress and success of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal is a great one. The creation of course content for community advisors will provide all community advisors with the fundamental procedures for assessing proposals, thus improving the reputation of (v) CAs and improving quality in the assessment and scoring of proposals. The innovative idea targets the problem of the ability of CAs to fully comprehend their role in the catalyst program. The structure of the initiative is well elaborated on, and if implemented is going to be beneficial for new CAs and address their challenges in terms of what the program expects of them. The function of CAs to the catalyst program is of immense importance in assessing which project is going to be beneficial to the Cardano system at large. Hence, the development of a course content which will educate CAs as to what their function is and result in an effective assessment of proposals will in the long run be of benefit to the Cardano system as well.
f6_assessments.q1: The well-elaborated time frames which clearly describes the stages and the resources involved for the completion of the project coupled with a reasonable and well-defined budget allocation which provides investors with a clear understanding of how every dime of the money is going to be utilized; makes it all the easier to achieve the proposals stated goals. I believe the team members from the developers, designers, and consultants down to the catalyst community members have the required skills and expertise capable of bringing the proposal to fruition.
f6_assessments.q2: The targeted problem, which is the ability to ensure that all CAs have adequate knowledge on their roles and functions in the Catalyst program was cut out from the onset. The provided feasible time frames and the clear definition of activities for every stage of the process in conjunction with the outlined vision of success for the proposal which serves as excellent key performance indicators, I believe this proposal has provided me with sufficient information towards the attainment of its goals and how the stated goals can be assessed effectively.

f6_assessments.q0: I became convinced after reading this proposal. My first initial thought was that I wouldn't be for it, but it became clear to me that there is a need for this. As a new CA myself, I find myself struggling to create what might be considered a "good" review. I've written a few that were likely FAR too long, and I've written some that might've been a bit too short. While I've developed my own evaluative criteria of what's important to me, I'd like to be more tuned in with what the community is looking for. So, just based on recent experience, I'm in favor of this proposal.
f6_assessments.q1: What's the motivation? At first, I thought the price tag was too expensive but the breakdown makes it clear where each bit of funding is going. The issue I'm seeing is the motivation for new CAs to take the time to use this platform. I could see committed community members flocking to this platform to align our interests with the greater Cardano community. They would be most aware and most motivated. But I'm skeptical of the awareness and motivation of more casual and/or newer CAs to feel the need to participate. Which I feel is where the greatest need is. I feel a lack of incentive and marketing strategy here.
f6_assessments.q2: I'm very satisfied with the thorough level of KPIs identified to measure the success of this proposal. Zero complaints.

f6_assessments.q0:
IMPACT:
Community Advisors and Veteran Community Advisors play an important role in the Project Catalyst process. Therefore, we need to keeping building new tools to improve their work, performance, activity, and the way the assess and deliver feedback to the Catalyst proposals. Establishing standards in the mission and performance of CAs assessments, will improve and ensure the proposers and the community involved in the Catalyst Proposal, have a better understanding when presenting and proposing ideas. In this context, this proposal recognizes a problem within the challenge that needs to be resolved. The proposer establishes the solution by the creating of a ‘CA Academy’ (a simple web-based e-learning platform), that will serve as a small seminar, where CAs will gather and get CA procedure and information, before taking the next step of assessing and reviewing proposals. I agree with the concept that experienced CAs should conduct the assessments phase adequately, by focusing on all the resources and guidelines that Project Catalyst provide for the community advisors. In addition, I also consider that this projected solution visibly conveys how it will add value to the Cardano Catalyst ecosystem, by delivering step-by-step educational content to ensure CAs have effectively learned the Catalyst stages, before they start connecting, interacting, and providing feedback to the community. It is important to mention that the key metrics and goals of this proposals are aligned with the challenges settings, since the goal is to reach quality assessments and adequate score rates on the proposals. Finally, this plan will potentially be able to address future challenge since the online tools will be offered openly for the access to all CAs around the globe. I would like to see this idea scale and reach the language translation availability for CAs who not native speakers are. 
Score given: 5
f6_assessments.q1:
FEASIBILITY:
The proposer delivers relevant skills and experience needed to implement the proposal. He is a community advisor, who has knowledge in building digital educational based on his professional title as a Software Engineer. He also has worked on developing various web-based platforms. I would encourage to please update and provide the active links where we can learn about the proposer and team experience with Cardano and Catalyst. I did find some social media references (LinkedIn professional account and Twitter mentions about the proposers), but it would be ideal that he makes sure to include this links within the proposal, to add more professionalism and validity to the project. I would also suggest providing the links of the websites and digital educational content he has previously created, as well. This is very important to add value to the feasibility of a proposal. On the other hand, the proposer offers timeline, and how this plan would take place. It is broken down into two major phases: educational content creation and the Web-App development process. I consider the proposer knows the steps required to implement this proposal. Moreover, the budget is clearly broken down into identifiable elements. This is the phase where the proposal would require a significant number of talents, which I would suggest describing and mention. It is important to provide as much information and details as possible. Even though, the proposal is well explained, we need to know who the human talented working behind a project is, to judge if the team possess the required abilities and skills for the project success and implementation. 
Score given: 3
f6_assessments.q2:
I consider that even though this proposal recognizes a problem and describes a solution for CAs training and online website tools to improve the role for community advisors in Project Catalyst, there is some information that needs to be added to audit the progress and the success of the proposal. Some of this missing information are the links and references for both, the main proposer, and the team behind the project, who will be working on the creation/ implementation of the website, and content curation. Additionally, the proposer mentions having experience with online educational content creation, I would suggest displaying the public links to these references to add professionalism and auditability to the proposal. On the other hand, the team provides a roadmap with a reasonable time frame (6 months) to implement both the educational and website interface execution. Finally, this proposal addresses a feasible solution based on the number of CAs enrolled and VCAs that will collaborate for the content creation, but again I would like to see those references and professional links to ensure the success of this proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: Proposal aims to address a challenge of CA competence and reputation which is in line with campaign goals. Added value to the community is clearly described. Additional scaling of solution would be possible if it proved effective.
f6_assessments.q1:
Type of team and experience required is specified although number of persons in a team is not. 
Budget is clear and sufficiently broken down. Amount of requested funds might be not enough for a proper educational web app, but precise numbers of material are not given. 
Timetable is realistic, but plan fails to describe technical requirements of the proposal. A more specific deliverable with technical aspects would allow to judge feasibility much better.
f6_assessments.q2: Milestones could be derived from project plan although a more detailed timetable would be of help. As the solution is an educational web-app , general auditing of its completion and success should not be a problem.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal aims to develop an e-learning platform with educational material for guiding individuals who want to become Catalyst community advisors. I am honestly not sure if the Catalyst community has a problem with low numbers of CAs joining each round because not enough introductory materials are present, or because the currently available ones are found in various forms / shapes and sizes. 

Would it be beneficial to have everything in one place for easy reference? Of course. Can this project turn into this type of hub or will it just add to the existing numbers of existing resources? Again, I do not know and overall I feel fairly neutral towards the proposal when considering the alignment with the challenge, the added value for the Cardano community and the scalability potential of this proposal.
f6_assessments.q1:
There is only limited information about the team, skills and experience behind the project and again, it is rather difficult to assess the team’s suitability to deliver on its promises. But also rightfully so, the proposer has identified that half of the work needs to come from experienced Catalyst community members. We do not have any signs throughout the proposal that the team has gathered support from such members. 
 
Budget-wise a modest request, with good enough captions and splits of the total amount requested. Time-wise the project would be split into two equal 3-months phases, first focused on content creation and the second on app development, with fairly limited additional details.  
 
Again a neutral opinion on whether the team can actually deliver on its promises.
f6_assessments.q2: If this project is implemented, I do not perceive any risks with regards to the potential for auditability, and the proposer rightfully identifies a number of key indicators to be used: number of CAs onboarded, number or certifications issued, satisfaction feedback forms, etc. I think the recipe for measuring the success of a training platform in general are rather known and fairly easy to implement, so I do not see major risks in not being able to keep track / audit this project if implemented.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal addresses the challenge because identifies the big problem most new CAs face when being overwhelmed with all the information they are exposed to without a clear guideline.  According to the project, the two phases of the execution plan would help first to learn from experienced members by receiving input to later put together a web to reflect the tools and other relevant information.
I do think the proposal is able to scale to address future challenges because content can always be updated and organized according to the ongoing feedback collected.
f6_assessments.q1:
It looks like the proposer is a well-experienced community member with a background in developing websites as an engineer so it is highly likely this proposal will be implemented successfully. 
The budget is expressed in detail based on the description of the different tasks to be performed and the cost of each of those tasks.
Even though it is not elaborated extensively, the plan defines the resources necessary to implement the proposal.
I believe the budget is reasonable for the amount of time and work described to be perfromed.
f6_assessments.q2:
The way to measure how to monitor the progress of the proposal is not expressed clearly since there are no tools mentioned to follow a roadmap. Having said this, the proposer expressed the plan in months needed, 3 for the first phase and 3 for the second phase with some overlap of the two phases.
KPIs are also listed but some of them don't define success, like "number of community advisors enrolled" (how many?) So it would be useful to have some goals to define success on those KPIs that don't have numbers.

f6_assessments.q0:
Creating a streamlined and automated onboarding will take a significant load of vCAs from answering questions in Telegram or Discord. This addresses the challenge very much at its core root.
The proposal describes well how the learning platform will foster the CAs learning experience to improve the general ability to assess proposals on common ground.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal in itself shows that the proposer has the relevant experience to implement or at least lead the implementation of the given plans.
The team members needed are yet to be found, but considering the activity in the community, one can be comfortable with the planning.
The budget seems reasonable and is broken down into identifiable chunks.
It is not entirely clear how the future costs will be carried and by whom.
3 months seems to be very ambitious for the project, but it is aligned with the active and positive sentiment of the community to improve catalyst for F9 already.
The timetable carefully lays out the phases and the milestones, that need to be accomplished. Special emphasis has been set towards communication between the different peer groups.
Developers, designers, content creators, and consultants are a good mix to connect the necessary dots of this undertaking.
Technicals are not given, so but it could be argued that as of this early stage those still need to be iterated.
The proposer outlines, how crucial it is to include experienced CAs and vCAs to be able to achieve the set goals.
f6_assessments.q2:
Creating a streamlined process for CA by setting a clear standard is in strong favor of the given challenge.
Currently, the information is scattered over various (Google) documents which creates confusion and reduces the learning efficiency, especially for new CAs. The summary could have already addressed, that the standard guide is going to be in an interactive form. This makes the proposal even more appealing.
The proposer shows the relevant experience to properly structure and set up the learning platform.
The requested funding seems to be adequate.
The roadmap is reasonably concise and timed.
Metrics are set in regards to advisors activity and general satisfaction of voters with the assessments' quality.
The well defined problem and solution statements are in close relationship to the given challenge and provide a great outlook for F9 and following funds.

f6_assessments.q0:
The problem statement of this proposal is vague question instead of a proven problem. However it aligns with the challenge objectives of “Build new tools to improve (v)CA's work” and “Develop reputation system(s) for (v)CAs”.
The proposed solution also aligns with the challenge metrics ” Number of new tools developed”, because by its essence it is an educational tool for CAs. However the solution puts a lot of weight on how the proposers and the community perceive the CAs and their understanding of the values of Project Catalyst, which is not aligned to the challenge objectives and goals.
Due to the essence of this solution is to be a e-learning platform for the new CAs, this proposal might be better aligned with the challenge New member onboarding https://cardano.ideascale.com/c/campaigns/26450/about  because the current challenge has the incline to “Community Advisors (CAs) submitting proposals as a Team to improve the CAs performance, activity and evolution.”  Although the proposal clearly shows how it will add value to the Catalyst ecosystem and therefore the Cardano ecosystem, the key metrics that this solution delivers are not well aligned with the challenge metrics.
However, because the proposal is peripheral on both challenges I neither agree nor disagree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal has a plan for action divided in two phases dividing the content creation work and the web app work. This brings good structure of the plan and there are further bullet points for more clarity. Unfortunately there is a lot of uncertainty in the way the information is presented, there is not enough detail to proof the existence of a detailed actionable plan. The total lack of actionable tasks is something that makes me cautious.  
The budget section of the proposal like the plan is partly broken down to components, but not sufficiently to satisfy the needs of the voter IMO. For example: “developers for 3 months $3000” how many developers, for how many hours at what price per hour stays a mystery. This broad strokes approach does not instill trust in the reader/voter/CA. The devil is in the details as the saying goes. I wish to recommend to the proposer in future proposals to pay special attention to the details of the proposal. I believe this will bring him success.
The team has not been outlined, again just broad strokes. There are no CV links to any member of the team, because there is no team yet. The proposer expects to take at face value his credibility which will be difficult in these days. I would strongly recommend for the next proposal the team to be clearly defined and tasks to be divided between the team, also a proper presentation and links to check the background for all team members.
I disagree that it is highly likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2:
On the auditability side of this proposal the voter would not find any measurable success parameters against which the auditor could compare the real results and the progress of the project. It is unclear how the auditor should make a decision on the success and the progress of the proposal. The proposer is referring to the timeline outlined earlier in the proposal, but the timeline and the action plan of the project are not sufficiently detailed to accommodate an auditability assessment build on top of them.
I strongly disagree that this proposal provides me with sufficient information to assess the progress in attaining its stated goals.
Dear proposer, I could not stress enough the benefits a proposer could get from reading highly assessed proposals from previous funds. I strongly recommend you spend some time and read a few of them. Also, the key to writing a good auditability section of the proposal is to put yourself in the shoes of the auditor and imagine what kind of information you will need to audit a proposal like yours.

f6_assessments.q0:
Having enjoyed a successful entry into CA work in Fund 7, I can see the value of this proposal in terms of providing a clear and official platform for learning the basics of CA work. Under the current system, learning how to do CA work right entailed a level of initiative and exploring on my part, and I was fine for it, but this also might make Catalyst feel disorganized and unreliable to a newcomer who is considering contributing for the first time. 

An official basic certification system could resolve that, and thus serve as an effective if very basic reputation standard while also helping newcomers understand what this work is all about more efficiently. Though personally I would like to see more accreditation based on successful work performed as a CA, since that is the ultimate meaningful metric.
f6_assessments.q1:
Given that this is a promising idea, it is disappointing that no information on the team members was presented. Some legwork here, before the proposal is put forward, would be necessary before I could consider successful implementation of this proposal likely. One or two team members assigned to the technical aspect should at least be on board and their credentials/experience noted clearly in the proposal. It's possible the lead proposer could even qualify for this, if they provided a bit more detail about their history and achievements on the technical side. A LinkedIn page, a github, anything...

That being said, the budget and plan contains sufficient information. It's just that the missing puzzle piece is an essential one.
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal should be a sure bet for the auditing process, as the whole Catalyst community and experienced CAs are invited to have direct involvement. The only issue I could see arising is reliably finding outsiders with an adequately external perspective to audit this project fairly. But this is likely to be a fully transparent project in the end and easily assess whether the project's success metrics have been reached.

f6_assessments.q0: While this project certainly aligns with the challenge setting, I am not seeing much value added to the system.  The idea to create a web-based class that CAs can take (I am assuming this is a voluntary proposition), which sounds like it will be asynchronous, is currently already being implemented by Catalyst School (which also has live presentations of the material, as well as 1 to 1 meetings).  I found it unclear whether the role here for veteran CAs was to be available as mentors to new CAs through the academy, or were to be assets consulted for the creation of the educational resources.  If a mentorship program, that would be an interesting twist, and with the intention of this program to award a credential for completing the course, the mentorship could act as a "verification protocol."  On that note, the suggestion of a credential in the proposal is intriguing, yet not described in any detail, or with any intent as to what the standards of credentialing would be.  We don't even know if it is for "passing" the class or just participating.  Overall the impact described here doesn't seem to add to what is already happening in the ecosystem, and at best is only an increase in existing bandwidth, a service perhaps better offered in collaboration with other resources, perhaps as an add-on app to the Catalyst School.
f6_assessments.q1: The general idea is laid out well enough, but I felt that critical components of the architecture are missing.  For example, the credential claim is perhaps the most interesting, yet the protocols for issuing and holding it are not described.  Is this going to be something provable like a DID?  An entry in a ledger to be cross-referenced by verifiers?  What is the wider role of the credential in the ecosystem, where would it have value?  (And it should be understood that its ability to hold value speaks to how that value was validated in the first place...that it is useful somewhere is the proof that the program suggested here has any impact).  The attention in both the timeline and budget is heavy to development work, and here is where I would have liked to have seen a much better list of team members, including their names and bios.  With no clarifications about the tech stack for the web platform, it is a complete unknown whether this team will be able to successfully implement this.
f6_assessments.q2: The auditability of this project really clarifies what is needed from the proposal, but which isn't present.  It purports to count the number of CAs enrolled...is this ones who participate but don't go on to become CAs, or is it only the certified ones?  It mentions the satisfaction of proposer's with the CAs who review them...  which is an anonymous process, so how exactly do the app protocols integrate to that, and, whether anonymous or not, how is that data to be collected or even understood?  The delivery of a learning app that provides existing educational content, or reformats it for an online class is certainly a deliverable, but what this project purports to do (onboard new CAs, raise CA quality) is not measurable within that context.  A project like this needs to have much better defined protocols in order to validate any claims to quality from its offerings, and a good way for the proposer to think about that is to consider the KPIs that they have suggested themselves under the "Success" description and really think about what the protocols would look like that can deliver those things in a provable way.  They are worthwhile goals to shoot for, and a learning app could definitely be a path to reach them, so I would recommend refining and improving this idea, collaborating with existing resources, and watching the space for the arrival of DIDs and VC compatibility.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal is aligned with the challenge in that it aims to support CAs' work and create CA resources, and will also have some impact on CA reputation. However,the proposal does not address the question of how this training dovetails with existing training for CAs, e.g. Catalyst School's videos and guides. If the different training materials are not aligned in some way, then the proposal could have the unintended effect of making the CA process and CA reputation *more* unclear, complex and frustrating, rather than less, if it means we end up with multiple standards.
f6_assessments.q1: The UX design and developers have been appropriately costed, but several other elements are under-resourced. First, project management: the proposal team clearly have the relevant skills and experience to manage the building of the platform, but it’s unclear whether the budget element of $500 for “coordinators incentive” refers to project-managing the developers and the build process, or to facilitating and coordinating the sessions with community members to brainstorm ideas, or both. If it’s only one of those, then the other should be added as a separate cost; and if it is meant to cover both, the money allocated to it is too low - the proposer has specifically recognised that a key risk of the project is co-ordinating the input of several people on content creation, so as a minimum attempt to mitigate that, there should be enough money to pay a skilled person for facilitating and coordinating that process. The content creation is also very under-resourced, at only $500. This is the core of the proposal - after all, without well-structured and effective learning content, the proposal will be useless no matter how beautiful the learning platform is - but as the proposer himself says, the balance of resources and time is all weighted towards the developers. This seems to be the wrong way round. Possibly, the reason for the low budget here is that the proposers intend to repurpose existing content, e.g. from Catalyst School - but if so, it feels like an oversight that they are not explicitly including existing CA guidance in their planning, and also that they're not including School as part of their plan. $1,500 is budgeted as an incentive for "experienced community members" to give their input, but the proposal doesn’t specify how many community members this will cover, or how much time they will be asked to give, so it is difficult to assess if it’s too low. There is no budget allocated for marketing and promotion of the certification, which feels like a major omission; there is also nothing for the time needed to evaluate and assess it to check that it is having the desired effects, even though the “auditability section recognises the need to audit this. There is also no recognition of the need to revise or fine-tune the course in the future - there are always changes to the CA process each fund, so the course will almost certainly need some updating by fund 10, so this proposal should probably have included some time and resources to enable the team to submit a continuation proposal to update it (and ideally, such a process should aim to liaise with the CA community and the CA sub-circle around any new changes to the process). My final question on feasibility is that the proposal is not clear whether this course is intended as a compulsory thing in order for someone to become a CA.  I am assuming not, because the proposal says nothing about how this would be managed and certificated, and how we could ensure that someone didn’t (for example) pretend to be certified when they are not; but if it is simply a voluntary thing that only some CAs will do, then this makes it all the more important that it is marketed and promoted well in order for people to know about it and value it. Overall, I see too many questions - particularly on budget - to feel sure that the project is feasible. No doubt something could be created - but would it serve the purpose when it is so under-resourced?
f6_assessments.q2: The project is auditable; it includes basic but sensible metrics, and it is particularly nice that the proposer has suggested auditing actual outcomes in terms of improved quality of CA assesments, rather than simply looking at numbers of people enrolled. My only issue re: audit is that I know from the Feasibility section that collating this kind of valuable feedback (e.g. are those who have done the course doing high-quality CA assessments or not?) has not actually been resourced, so it will be practically difficult to audit this.
